## Licenses and Acknowledgements for Incorporated Software

This component contains software licensed under different licenses when compiled, please refer to the third-party-licenses.md file for further information and full license texts.

## Authentication:

Supports OAuth2 [Authorization Code Flow](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-4.1),
at paths described in the [OpenID Connect Discovery metadata document](None)
Microsoft Identity Platform
([documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/v2-oauth2-auth-code-flow)).

Authentication can be turned off with `OAUTH_ENABLED=false` environment variable. 

When authentication is turned on, all requests to API endpoints must provide a valid bearer (JWT) token inside the `Authorization` http header. 

When authentication is turned off, all endpoints accept (optional) custom header `X-Test-User-Id` which 
allows any request to specify any user id value. If the `X-Test-User-Id` header is missing, the default value of `unknown-user` is assumed.

get.summary: Return every variable related to the selected status and version of the ODM Templates

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By
schema.description:

- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

schema.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

parameters.description:
Number of items to be returned per page.

Default: 10

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

parameters.name: page_size

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

parameters.description:
Boolean value specifying whether total count of entities should be included in the reponse.

Functionality: retrieve total count of queried entities.

schema.title: Total Count
schema.description:
Boolean value specifying whether total count of entities should be included in the reponse.

Functionality: retrieve total count of queried entities.

parameters.name: total_count

schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Template.

204.description: No Content - The ODM Template was successfully deleted.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The ODM Template is not in draft status.
- The ODM Template was already in final state or is in use.
- The library does not allow to delete ODM Template.

404.description: Not Found - An ODM Template with the specified 'uid' could not be found.

Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The ODM Template is not in draft status.
- The ODM Template had been in 'Final' status before.
- The library does not allow to edit draft versions.

404.description: Not Found - The ODM Template with the specified 'uid' wasn't found.

get.summary: List version history for ODM Template
get.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist.

Business logic:
 - List version history for ODM Templates.
 - The returned versions are ordered by start_date descending (newest entries first).

State after:
 - No change

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid.

parameters.description: The unique id of the ODM Template.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Template.

parameters.name: uid

schema.title: Response Get Odm Template Versions Concepts Odms Templates  Uid  Versions Get

404.description: Not Found - The ODM Template with the specified 'uid' wasn't found.

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Template
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Template must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Template is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Template changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

parameters.description: The unique id of the ODM Template.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Template.

parameters.name: uid

201.description: OK.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create ODM Templates.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The ODM Template is not in final status.
- The ODM Template with the specified 'uid' could not be found.

State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Form must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Form is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Form changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Item
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Item must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Item is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Item changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Condition
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Condition must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Condition is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Condition changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

parameters.description: The unique id of the ODM Condition.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Condition.

parameters.name: uid

201.description: OK.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create ODM Conditions.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The ODM Condition is not in final status.
- The ODM Condition with the specified 'uid' could not be found.

get.summary: Return every variable related to the selected status and version of the ODM Methods

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

get.summary: List version history for ODM Formal Expression
get.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist.

Business logic:
 - List version history for ODM Formal Expressions.
 - The returned versions are ordered by start_date descending (newest entries first).

State after:
 - No change

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid.

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Formal Expression
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Formal Expression must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Formal Expression is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Formal Expression changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

parameters.description: The unique id of the ODM Formal Expression.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Formal Expression.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types.

post.summary: Create a new version of an ODM Description
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Description must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Description is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Description changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Vendor Namespace
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Vendor Namespace must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Vendor Namespace is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Vendor Namespace changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

parameters.description: The unique id of the ODM Vendor Namespace.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the ODM Vendor Namespace.

201.description: OK.

403.description:

- The library does not allow to create ODM Vendor Namespaces.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The ODM Vendor Namespace is not in final status.
- The ODM Vendor Namespace with the specified 'uid' could not be found.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.

Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

 - No change

 - Invalid uid.

post.summary: Create a new version of ODM Vendor Element
post.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and the ODM Vendor Element must be in status Final.

Business logic:
- The ODM Vendor Element is changed to a draft state.

State after:
 - ODM Vendor Element changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating a new draft version.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Final.

This may be particularly useful if the activity description template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.

post.summary: Creates a new activity description template in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the activity description template
* belongs to a library that allows creating (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.
* The activity description template will be linked to a library.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an activity description template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an activity description is created out of the activity description template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The activity description template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same activity description template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

schema.title: Search String
schema.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

parameters.name: search_string

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

Parameters in the 'name' property can only be changed if the activity description template has never been approved.
Once the activity description template has been approved, only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an activity description template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an activity description is created out of the activity description template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The activity description template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same activity description template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types.

post.summary: Creates a new criteria template in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the criteria template
* belongs to a library that allows creating (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.
* The criteria template will be linked to a library.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an criteria template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an criteria is created out of the criteria template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The criteria template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same criteria template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

* the criteria template is in 'Draft' status and
* the criteria template has never been in 'Final' status and
* the criteria template has no references to any criteria and
* the criteria template belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

patch.summary: Updates the criteria template identified by 'uid'.
patch.description:
This request is only valid if the criteria template
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

Parameters in the 'name' property can only be changed if the criteria template has never been approved.
Once the criteria template has been approved, only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an criteria template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an criteria is created out of the criteria template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The criteria template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same criteria template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

post.summary: Creates a new version of the criteria template identified by 'uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the criteria template
* is in 'Final' or 'Retired' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists) and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version will remain the same as before.
* The status of the new version will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version increased by +0.1.

Parameters in the 'name' property cannot be changed with this request.
Only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

get.summary: Returns a specific version of a specific criteria template identified by 'uid' and 'version'.
get.description:
**Multiple versions**:

Technically, there can be multiple versions of the criteria template with the same version number. This is due to the fact, that the version number remains the same when inactivating or reactivating an criteria template (switching between 'Final' and 'Retired' status). 

In that case the latest/newest representation is returned.

A specific version number of the criteria template. The version number is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits.
E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

schema.description:
A specific version number of the criteria template. The version number is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits.
E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

post.summary: Validates the content of an criteria template without actually processing it.
post.description:
Be aware that - even if this request is accepted - there is no guarantee that
a following request to e.g. *[POST] /criteria-templates* or *[PATCH] /criteria-templates/{uid}*
with the same content will succeed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an criteria template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an criteria is created out of the criteria template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The criteria template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same criteria template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

schema.description: The content of the criteria template that shall be validated.

202.description: Accepted. The content is valid and may be submitted in another request.

403.description:
Forbidden. The content is invalid - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The syntax of the 'name' is not valid.
- One of the parameters wasn't found.

get.summary: Returns the latest/newest version of a specific criteria identified by 'uid'.
get.description:
If multiple request query parameters are used, then they need to
    match all at the same time (they are combined with the AND operation).

parameters.description: The unique id of the criteria.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the criteria.

parameters.name: uid

parameters.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the criteria at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

schema.title: At Specified Date Time
schema.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the criteria at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.name: at_specified_date_time

parameters.description:
If specified, the representation of the criteria in that status is returned (if existent). This may be particularly useful if the criteria has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified, the representation of the criteria in that status is returned (if existent). This may be particularly useful if the criteria has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description: If specified, the latest/newest representation of the criteria in that version is returned. Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

schema.title: Version
schema.description: If specified, the latest/newest representation of the criteria in that version is returned. Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

This request is only valid if 

* the criteria is in 'Draft' status and
* the criteria has never been in 'Final' status and
* the criteria belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

post.description:
This request is only valid if the criteria
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description: Parameter specifies which parts of the whole Study Definition representation to retrieve. In the form of comma separated name of the fields prefixed by (optional) `+`  if the client wishes to retrieve the field or `-` if the client wants to skip the field. If not specified identification metadata and version metadata are retrieved. If value starts with `+` or `-` above default is extended or reduced by the specified fields otherwise (if not started with `+` or `-`) provided fields specification replaces the default. Currently supported fields are `current_metadata.identification_metadata`, `current_metadata.high_level_study_design` , `current_metadata.study_population` and `current_metadata.study_intervention` , `current_metadata.study_description`.

schema.description: Parameter specifies which parts of the whole Study Definition representation to retrieve. If not specified identification metadata and version metadata are retrieved. If value starts with `+` or `-` above default is extended or reduced by the specified fields otherwise (if not started with `+` or `-`) provided fields specification replaces the default. Currently supported fields are `current_metadata.identification_metadata`, `current_metadata.high_level_study_design` , `current_metadata.study_population` and `current_metadata.study_intervention` , `current_metadata.study_description`.

get.description:
Returns all template parameters used in the criteria template
that is the basis for the criteria identified by 'uid'. 
Includes the available values per parameter.

The returned parameters are ordered

Per parameter, the parameter.values are ordered by
0. value.name ascending

Note that parameters may be used multiple times in templates.
In that case, the same parameter (with the same values) is included multiple times in the response.

get.summary: Returns all objective templates in their latest/newest version.
get.description: Allowed parameters include : filter on fields, sort by field name with sort direction, pagination

parameters.description:
If specified, only those objective templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified, only those objective templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.name: sort_by

parameters.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

schema.title: Page Number
schema.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

parameters.name: page_number

parameters.description:
Number of items to be returned per page.

Default: 10

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

schema.title: Page Size
schema.description:
Number of items to be returned per page.

Default: 10

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

parameters.name: page_size

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

parameters.description:
Boolean value specifying whether total count of entities should be included in the reponse.

Functionality: retrieve total count of queried entities.

schema.title: Total Count

Functionality: retrieve total count of queried entities.

parameters.name: total_count

post.summary: Creates a new objective template in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the objective template
* belongs to a library that allows creating (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.
* The objective template will be linked to a library.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an objective template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an objective is created out of the objective template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The objective template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same objective template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

patch.summary: Updates the objective template identified by 'uid'.
patch.description:
This request is only valid if the objective template
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

Parameters in the 'name' property can only be changed if the objective template has never been approved.
Once the objective template has been approved, only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an objective template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an objective is created out of the objective template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The objective template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same objective template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

get.summary: Returns possible values from the database for a given header
get.description:
Allowed parameters include : field name for which to get possible
    values, search string to provide filtering for the field name, additional filters to apply on other fields

parameters.description:
If specified, only those objective templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified, only those objective templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
The field name for which to lookup possible values in the database.

Functionality: searches for possible values (aka 'headers') of this field in the database.Errors: invalid field name specified

schema.title: Field Name
schema.description:
The field name for which to lookup possible values in the database.

Functionality: searches for possible values (aka 'headers') of this field in the database.Errors: invalid field name specified

parameters.name: field_name

parameters.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

schema.title: Search String
schema.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

parameters.name: search_string

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

parameters.description: Optionally, the number of results to return. Default = 10.

schema.description: Optionally, the number of results to return. Default = 10.

get.summary: Returns the latest/newest version of a specific objective identified by 'uid'.
get.description:
If multiple request query parameters are used, then they need to
    match all at the same time (they are combined with the AND operation).

parameters.description: The unique id of the objective.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the objective.

parameters.name: uid

parameters.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the objective at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

schema.title: At Specified Date Time
schema.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the objective at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.name: at_specified_date_time

parameters.description:
If specified, the representation of the objective in that status is returned (if existent). This may be particularly useful if the objective has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status

Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description: If specified, the latest/newest representation of the objective in that version is returned. Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

schema.title: Version
schema.description: If specified, the latest/newest representation of the objective in that version is returned. Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

delete.summary: Deletes the objective identified by 'uid'.

This request is only valid if 

* the objective is in 'Draft' status and
* the objective has never been in 'Final' status and
* the objective belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

patch.description:
This request is only valid if the objective
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

parameters.description: Parameter specifies which parts of the whole Study Definition representation to retrieve. In the form of comma separated name of the fields prefixed by (optional) `+`  if the client wishes to retrieve the field or `-` if the client wants to skip the field. If not specified identification metadata and version metadata are retrieved. If value starts with `+` or `-` above default is extended or reduced by the specified fields otherwise (if not started with `+` or `-`) provided fields specification replaces the default. Currently supported fields are `current_metadata.identification_metadata`, `current_metadata.high_level_study_design` , `current_metadata.study_population` and `current_metadata.study_intervention` , `current_metadata.study_description`.

schema.title: Fields
schema.description: Parameter specifies which parts of the whole Study Definition representation to retrieve. In the form of comma separated name of the fields prefixed by (optional) `+`  if the client wishes to retrieve the field or `-` if the client wants to skip the field. If not specified identification metadata and version metadata are retrieved. If value starts with `+` or `-` above default is extended or reduced by the specified fields otherwise (if not started with `+` or `-`) provided fields specification replaces the default. Currently supported fields are `current_metadata.identification_metadata`, `current_metadata.high_level_study_design` , `current_metadata.study_population` and `current_metadata.study_intervention` , `current_metadata.study_description`.

post.summary: Previews the creation of a new objective.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified objective template is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating objectives (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true) and
* the objective does not yet exist (no objective with the same content in 'Final' or 'Draft' status).

If the request succeeds:
* No objective will be created, but the result of the request will show what the objective will look like.

schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

200.description: Success - The objective is able to be created.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The provided list of parameters is invalid.
- The library does not allow to create objectives.
- The objective does already exist.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library with the specified 'library_name' could not be found.
- The objective template with the specified 'objective_template_uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approves the objective identified by 'uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the objective
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

* The 'version' property will remain the same as before.

get.description: Allowed parameters include : filter on fields, sort by field name with sort direction, pagination

parameters.description:
If specified, only those endpoint templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the endpoint template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified, only those endpoint templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the endpoint template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.name: sort_by

parameters.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

schema.title: Page Number
schema.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

parameters.name: page_number
