Number of items to be returned per page.

Default: 10

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

post.summary: Creates a new endpoint template in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the endpoint template
* belongs to a library that allows creating (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.
* The endpoint template will be linked to a library.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an endpoint template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an endpoint is created out of the endpoint template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /template-parameters/* endpoint for available parameters and their values.

The endpoint template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same endpoint template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='This is my endpoint for [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.description:
If specified, only those objective templates will be returned that are currently in the specified status. This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status

This may be particularly useful if the objective template has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

The field name for which to lookup possible values in the database.

Functionality: searches for possible values (aka 'headers') of this field in the database.Errors: invalid field name specified

parameters.name: field_name

parameters.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

schema.title: Search String
schema.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

parameters.name: search_string

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

delete.summary: Deletes the endpoint template identified by 'uid'.
delete.description:
This request is only valid if 

* the endpoint template is in 'Draft' status and
* the endpoint template has never been in 'Final' status and
* the endpoint template has no references to any endpoints and
* the endpoint template belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

patch.summary: Updates the endpoint template identified by 'uid'.
patch.description:
This request is only valid if the endpoint template
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

Parameters in the 'name' property can only be changed if the endpoint template has never been approved.
Once the endpoint template has been approved, only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an endpoint template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an endpoint is created out of the endpoint template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /template-parameters/* endpoint for available parameters and their values.

The endpoint template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same endpoint template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='This is my endpoint for [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

parameters.description: The unique id of the endpoint template.

post.summary: Creates a new version of the endpoint template identified by 'uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the endpoint template
* is in 'Final' or 'Retired' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists) and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version will remain the same as before.
* The status of the new version will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version increased by +0.1.

Parameters in the 'name' property cannot be changed with this request.
Only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

get.summary: Returns all final versions of objectives referenced by any study.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

post.summary: Creates a new endpoint in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified endpoint template is in 'Final' status and
* the specified objective is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating endpoints (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true) and
* the endpoint does not yet exist (no endpoint with the same content in 'Final' or 'Draft' status).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.

schema.title: Search String
schema.description:
Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.
The query result will be values of the field that contain the provided search string.

parameters.name: search_string

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the endpoint at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.description: Parameter specifies which parts of the whole Study Definition representation to retrieve. In the form of comma separated name of the fields prefixed by (optional) `+`  if the client wishes to retrieve the field or `-` if the client wants to skip the field. If not specified identification metadata and version metadata are retrieved. If value starts with `+` or `-` above default is extended or reduced by the specified fields otherwise (if not started with `+` or `-`) provided fields specification replaces the default. Currently supported fields are `current_metadata.identification_metadata`, `current_metadata.high_level_study_design` , `current_metadata.study_population` and `current_metadata.study_intervention` , `current_metadata.study_description`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

post.summary: Creates a new timeframe template in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the timeframe template
* belongs to a library that allows creating (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.
* The timeframe template will be linked to a library.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an timeframe template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an timeframe is created out of the timeframe template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The timeframe template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same timeframe template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

patch.summary: Updates the timeframe template identified by 'uid'.
patch.description:
This request is only valid if the timeframe template
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

Parameters in the 'name' property can only be changed if the timeframe template has never been approved.
Once the timeframe template has been approved, only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

**Parameters in the 'name' property**:

The 'name' of an timeframe template may contain parameters, that can - and usually will - be replaced with
concrete values once an timeframe is created out of the timeframe template.

Parameters are referenced by simple strings in square brackets [] that match existing parameters defined in the MDR repository.

See the *[GET] /parameter-templates/* endpoint for available values.

The timeframe template will be linked to those parameters defined in the 'name' property.

You may use an arbitrary number of parameters and you may use the same parameter multiple times within the same timeframe template 'name'.

*Example*:

name='MORE TESTING of the superiority in the efficacy of [Intervention] with [Activity] and [Activity] in [Timeframe].'

'Intervention', 'Activity' and 'Timeframe' are parameters.

post.description:
This request is only valid if the timeframe template
* is in 'Final' or 'Retired' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists) and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version will remain the same as before.
* The status of the new version will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version increased by +0.1.

Parameters in the 'name' property cannot be changed with this request.
Only the surrounding text (excluding the parameters) can be changed.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.name: sort_by

parameters.description:
Page number of the returned list of entities.

Functionality : provided together with `page_size`, selects a page to retrieve for paginated results.

Errors: `page_size` not provided, `page_number` must be equal or greater than 1.

schema.title: Page Number
schema.description:

Default: 10

Functionality: Provided together with `page_number`, selects the number of results per page.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

In case the value is set to `0`, all rows will be returned.

Errors: `page_number` not provided.

parameters.name: page_size

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

post.summary: Creates a new timeframe in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified timeframe template is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating timeframes (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true) and
* the timeframe does not yet exist (no timeframe with the same content in 'Final' or 'Draft' status).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be set to '0.1'.

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

schema.title: X-Test-User-Id
schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.name: x-test-user-id

schema.title: Timeframe
schema.description: Related parameters of the timeframe that shall be created.

201.description: Created - The timeframe was successfully created.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The provided list of parameters is invalid.
- The library does not allow to create timeframes.
- The timeframe does already exist.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library with the specified 'library_name' could not be found.
- The timeframe template with the specified 'timeframe_template_uid' could not be found.

get.summary: Returns the latest/newest version of a specific timeframe identified by 'uid'.
get.description:
If multiple request query parameters are used, then they need to
    match all at the same time (they are combined with the AND operation).

parameters.description: The unique id of the timeframe.

schema.title: Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the timeframe.

parameters.name: uid

parameters.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the timeframe at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

schema.title: At Specified Date Time
schema.description:
If specified, the latest/newest representation of the timeframe at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is ommitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.name: at_specified_date_time

parameters.description:
If specified, the representation of the timeframe in that status is returned (if existent). This may be particularly useful if the timeframe has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified, the representation of the timeframe in that status is returned (if existent). This may be particularly useful if the timeframe has a) a 'Draft' and a 'Final' status or b) a 'Draft' and a 'Retired' status at the same time and you are interested in the 'Final' or 'Retired' status.
Valid values are: 'Final', 'Draft' or 'Retired'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description: If specified, the latest/newest representation of the timeframe in that version is returned. Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format: \<major\>.\<minor\> where \<major\> and \<minor\> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0', ...

* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

This request is only valid if
* the specified timeframe template is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating timeframe (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true) and
* the timeframe does not yet exist (no timeframe with the same content in 'Final' or 'Draft' status).

post.summary: Approves the timeframe identified by 'uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the timeframe
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

get.summary: Returns the latest/newest version of a specific codelist identified by 'uid'

parameters.name: codelist_uid

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

schema.title: At Specified Date Time
schema.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.name: at_specified_date_time

parameters.description:
If specified then the representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue in that status is returned (if existent).
_this is useful if the CTCodelistAttributesValue has a status 'Draft' and a status 'Final'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified then the representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue in that status is returned (if existent).
_this is useful if the CTCodelistAttributesValue has a status 'Draft' and a status 'Final'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue in that version is returned.
Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format:<major>.<minor> where <major> and <minor> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0',

schema.title: Version
schema.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistAttributesValue in that version is returned.
Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format:<major>.<minor> where <major> and <minor> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0',

patch.description:
This request is only valid if the codelist
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The codelist is not in draft status.
- The codelist had been in 'Final' status before.
- The library does not allow to edit draft versions.

404.description: Not Found - The codelist with the specified 'codelist_uid' wasn't found.

post.summary: Creates a new codelist in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified codelist is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating codelists (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'new-version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased by '0.1'.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTCodelistAttributes

schema.title: Codelist Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the CTCodelistAttributes

parameters.name: codelist_uid

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

schema.title: X-Test-User-Id
schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.name: x-test-user-id

201.description: Created - The codelist was successfully created.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create codelists.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The codelist is not in final status.
- The codelist with the specified 'codelist_uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approves the codelist identified by 'codelist_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the codelist
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'Approved version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTCodelistAttributes

schema.description: The unique id of the CTCodelistAttributes

- The library does not allow to approve codelist.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the sponsor defined name for CTCodelistNameValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

This request is only valid if the codelist

* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

post.summary: Creates a new codelist in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified codelist is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating codelists (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'new-version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased by '0.1'.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create codelists.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The codelist is not in final status.
- The codelist with the specified 'codelist_uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approves the codelist identified by 'codelist_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the codelist
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'Approved version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

get.summary: Returns the latest/newest version of a specific ct term identified by 'term_uid'

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

schema.title: Term Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

parameters.name: term_uid

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the CTTermAttributesValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

schema.title: At Specified Date Time
schema.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the CTTermAttributesValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

parameters.name: at_specified_date_time

parameters.description:
If specified then the representation of the CTTermAttributesValue in that status is returned (if existent).
_this is useful if the CTTermAttributesValue has a status 'Draft' and a status 'Final'.

schema.title: Status
schema.description:
If specified then the representation of the CTTermAttributesValue in that status is returned (if existent).
_this is useful if the CTTermAttributesValue has a status 'Draft' and a status 'Final'.

parameters.name: status

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the for CTTermAttributesValue in that version is returned.
Only exact matches are considered. The version is specified in the following format:<major>.<minor> where <major> and <minor> are digits. E.g. '0.1', '0.2', '1.0',

delete.summary: Deletes the term identified by 'term_uid'.
delete.description:
This request is only valid if 

* the term is in 'Draft' status and
* the term has never been in 'Final' status and
* the term belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

schema.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

parameters.name: term_uid

schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.name: x-test-user-id

204.description: No Content - The term was successfully deleted.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in draft status.
- The term was already in final state or is in use.
- The library does not allow to delete term.

404.description: Not Found - An term with the specified 'term_uid' could not be found.

patch.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

403.description:

- The term had been in 'Final' status before.
- The library does not allow to edit draft versions.

post.summary: Creates a new term in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified term is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating term (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'new-version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased by '0.1'.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

schema.title: Term Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

parameters.name: term_uid

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

schema.title: X-Test-User-Id
schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.name: x-test-user-id

201.description: Created - The term was successfully created.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create tterm.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in final status.
- The term with the specified 'codelist_uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approves the term identified by 'term_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'Approved version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

schema.title: Term Uid
schema.description: The unique id of the CTTermAttributes

parameters.name: term_uid

parameters.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

schema.description: A value to be injected into service as user id.

parameters.name: x-test-user-id

201.description: OK.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in draft status.
- The library does not allow to approve term.

404.description: Not Found - The term with the specified 'term_uid' wasn't found.

post.summary: Reactivates the term identified by 'term_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Retired' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically. 
* The 'version' property will remain the same as before.

delete.summary: Inactivates/deactivates the term identified by 'term_uid'.
delete.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Final' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Retired'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically. 
* The 'version' property will remain the same as before.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

Optionally, a (part of the) text for a given field.

parameters.name: search_string

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

parameters.description:
If specified then the latest/newest representation of the CTTermNameValue at this point in time is returned.
The point in time needs to be specified in ISO 8601 format including the timezone, e.g.: '2020-10-31T16:00:00+02:00' for October 31, 2020 at 4pm in UTC+2 timezone. If the timezone is omitted, UTC±0 is assumed.

delete.summary: Deletes the term identified by 'term_uid'.
delete.description:
This request is only valid if 

* the term is in 'Draft' status and
* the term has never been in 'Final' status and
* the term belongs to a library that allows deleting (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

204.description: No Content - The term was successfully deleted.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in draft status.
- The term was already in final state or is in use.
- The library does not allow to delete term.

404.description: Not Found - An term with the specified 'term_uid' could not be found.

patch.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true). 

If the request succeeds:
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically by +0.1.
* The status will remain in 'Draft'.

- The library does not allow to edit draft versions.

post.summary: Creates a new term in 'Draft' status.
post.description:
This request is only valid if
* the specified term is in 'Final' status and
* the specified library allows creating term (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'new-version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased by '0.1'.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermNames

201.description: Created - The term was successfully created.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create tterm.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in final status.
- The term with the specified 'codelist_uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approves the term identified by 'term_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Draft' status and
* belongs to a library that allows editing (the 'is_editable' property of the library needs to be true).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'Approved version'.
* The 'version' property will be increased automatically to the next major version.

parameters.description: The unique id of the CTTermNames

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The term is not in draft status.
- The library does not allow to approve term.

404.description: Not Found - The term with the specified 'term_uid' wasn't found.

post.summary: Reactivates the term identified by 'term_uid'.
post.description:
This request is only valid if the term
* is in 'Retired' status only (so no latest 'Draft' status exists).

If the request succeeds:
* The status will be automatically set to 'Final'.
* The 'change_description' property will be set automatically. 
* The 'version' property will remain the same as before.

Business logic:
 - List all dictionary codelists (in their latest versions).
 
State after:
 - No change

Possible errors:
 - Invalid library name.

schema.description: The Library from which the dictionaries codelists should be retrieved

parameters.name: library

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

patch.summary: Update name or template parameter flag for dictionary codelist
patch.description:
State before:
 - codelist_uid must exist and the dictionary codelist must exist in status draft.
 
Business logic:
 - If the dictionary codelist related to codelist_uid exist in status draft then name attribute and Template Parameter node label are updated.
 - If Template Parameter have been set to 'Y' then it cannot be set back to 'N' (i.e. when the Template Parameter node label have been added it cannot be removed).
 
State after:
 - name attribute and Template Parameter node label are updated for the dictionary codelist.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with update of name attribute or Template Parameter flag.
 
Possible errors:
 - Invalid codelist_uid.

post.summary: Create a new version of the dictionary codelist
post.description:
State before:
 - codelist_uid must exist and the dictionary codelist must be in status Final.
 
Business logic:
 - The latest 'Final' version will remain the same as before.
 - The status of the new created version will be automatically set to 'Draft'.
 - The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' or 'Retired' version increased by +0.1.
 - The 'change_description' property will be set automatically to 'New version'.
 
State after:
 - Dictionary codelist changed status to Draft and assigned a new minor version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of creating new Draft version.
 
Possible errors:
 - Invalid codelist_uid or status not Final.

403.description:
Forbidden - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The library does not allow to create codelists.

404.description:
Not Found - Reasons include e.g.: 
- The dictionary codelist is not in final status.
- The dictionary codelist with the specified 'uid' could not be found.

post.summary: Approve draft version of the dictionary codelist
post.description:
State before:
 - codelist_uid must exist and the dictionary codelist must be in status Draft.
 
Business logic:
 - The latest 'Draft' version will remain the same as before.
 - The status of the new approved version will be automatically set to 'Final'.
 - The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' version increased by +1.0.
 - The 'change_description' property will be set automatically 'Approved version'.
 
State after:
 - Dictionary codelist changed status to Final and assigned a new major version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of approving to new Final version.
 
Possible errors:
 - Invalid codelist_uid or status not Draft.

post.summary: Attaches a dictionary term to a dictionary codelist
post.description:
State before:
 - Codelist identified by uid must exist.

Business logic:
 - Create a HAS_TERM relationship between the selected codelist root and the selected term root, with the current date and current user.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid codelist_uid.
-  Invalid term_uid.
-  Codelist with {uid} is not extensible.
- Term is already part of the specified codelist.

- The dictionary term does not exist.
- The dictionary codelist already has passed term.

delete.summary: Removes a dictionary term from a dictionary codelist
delete.description:
State before:
 - Codelist identified by codelist_uid must exist.
 - Term identified by term_uid must exist.
 - Codelist contains the term that is being removed.


Business logic:
 - Create a HAD_TERM relationship between the selected codelist root and the selected term root, with the current date as the end date, and current user.
 - Remove the old HAS_TERM relationship between the codelist and the term.

Possible errors:
 - Invalid codelist_uid.
 - Invalid term_uid.
- Term is not part of the specified codelist.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and boolean flags specifying the sort order. Supported values for sort order are:
- `true` - ascending order

- `false` - descending order


Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

schema.title: Sort By

- `true` - ascending order

Default: `{}` (no sorting).

Format: `{"field_1": true, "field_2": false, ...}`.

Functionality: Sorts the results by `field_1` with sort order indicated by its boolean value, then by `field_2` etc.

Example: `{"topic_code": true, "name": false}` sorts the returned list by `topic_code ascending`, then by `name descending`.

parameters.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

schema.title: Filters
schema.description:
JSON dictionary of field names and search strings, with a choice of operators for building complex filtering queries.

Default: `{}` (no filtering).

Functionality: filters the queried entities based on the provided search strings and operators.

Format:
`{"field_name":{"v":["search_str_1", "search_str_1"], "op":"comparison_operator"}, "other_field_name":{...}}`

- `v` specifies the list of values to match against the specified `field_name` field

    - If multiple values are provided in the `v` list, a logical OR filtering operation will be performed using these values.

- `op` specifies the type of string match/comparison operation to perform on the specified `field_name` field. Supported values are:

    - `eq` (default, equals)

    - `ne` (not equals)

    - `co` (string contains)

    - `ge` (greater or equal to)

    - `gt` (greater than)

    - `le` (less or equal to)

    - `lt` (less than)

    - `bw` (between - exactly two values are required)

    - `in` (value in list).


Note that filtering can also be performed on non-string field types. 
For example, this works as filter on a boolean field: `{"is_global_standard": {"v": [false]}}`.


Wildcard filtering is also supported. To do this, provide `*` value for `field_name`, for example: `{"*":{"v":["search_string"]}}`.

Wildcard only supports string search (with implicit `contains` operator) on fields of type string.


Finally, you can filter on items that have an empty value for a field. To achieve this, set the value of `v` list to an empty array - `[]`.


Complex filtering example:

`{"name":{"v": ["Jimbo", "Jumbo"], "op": "co"}, "start_date": {"v": ["2021-04-01T12:00:00+00.000"], "op": "ge"}, "*":{"v": ["wildcard_search"], "op": "co"}}`

parameters.name: filters

parameters.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

schema.title: Operator
schema.description:
Specifies which logical operation - `and` or `or` - should be used in case filtering is done on several fields.

Default: `and` (all fields have to match their filter).

Functionality: `and` will return entities having all filters matching, `or` will return entities with any matches.

parameters.name: operator

patch.description:
State before:
 - uid must exist and dictionary term must exist in status draft.
 
Business logic:
 - For SNOMED: Updates can only be imported from the SNOMED files, webservice or from legacy migration.
 - It should not be possible to update from the study builder app, this we can do with access permissions later.
 - The existing dictionary term is updated.
 - The individual values for name and uid must all be unique values within the dictionary codelist.
 - The status of the updated version will continue to be 'Draft'.
 - The 'version' property of the version will automatically be incremented with +0.1.
 - The 'change_description' property is required.
 
State after:
 - Attribute are updated for the dictionary term.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with update of attributes.
 
Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid.

State before:
 - uid must exist and the dictionary term must be in status Draft.
 
Business logic:
 - The latest 'Draft' version will remain the same as before.
 - The status of the new approved version will be automatically set to 'Final'.
 - The 'version' property of the new version will be automatically set to the version of the latest 'Final' version increased by +1.0.
 - The 'change_description' property will be set automatically 'Approved version'.
 
State after:
 - dictionary term changed status to Final and assigned a new major version number.
 - Audit trail entry must be made with action of approving to new Final version.
 
Possible errors:
 - Invalid uid or status not Draft.
